Context: A panel of five scientists will be formed. The panelists will be selected from among three botanists—F, G, and H—three chemists—K, L, and M—and three zoologists—P, Q, and R. Selection is governed by the following conditions: The panel must include at least one scientist of each of the three types. If more than one botanist is selected, then at most one zoologist is selected. F and K cannot both be selected. K and M cannot both be selected. If M is selected, both P and R must be selected.
Question: If four of the scientists selected are F, L, Q, and R, which one of the following must be the fifth scientist selected?
Choices:
  A: G
  B: H
  C: K
  D: M
  E: P

The panel must include at least one scientist of each of the three types, so we need to select a botanist, a chemist, and a zoologist.
We already have a botanist (F), a chemist (L), and two zoologists (Q and R).
Since more than one botanist is not allowed if more than one zoologist is selected, we cannot select another botanist.
Since F and [REDACTED] cannot both be selected, we cannot select [REDACTED].
Since [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] cannot both be selected, we cannot select [REDACTED].
Since [REDACTED] is not selected, we do not need to select both [REDACTED] and R.
Therefore, the only remaining option is another zoologist.
